docs.lead_paragraph: One of the most crucial bonds between patient and physician is the absolute promise of confidentiality. Most people are simply not comfortable discussing sensitive topics unless this promise is proffered and strictly upheld. Because it is impossible to predict what might shame one person but not another, doctors pledge confidentiality to all, with the proviso that they may discuss cases with medical colleagues to provide better care and, in much rarer instances, with legal authorities, when a child is being abused, for example.

headline.main: When Big Brother Invades the Examining Room

docs.abstract: Importance of confidentiality between doctor and patient discussed; political, judicial, and moral aspects of medical oath that guarantees privacy described; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: One of the most crucial bonds between patient and physician is the absolute promise of confidentiality. Most people are simply not comfortable discussing sensitive topics unless this promise is proffered and strictly upheld.    Because it is...

docs.lead_paragraph: It may seem obvious that everyone in a theater is watching the same movie. But when neuroscientists popped test subjects into a brain scanner to see ''The Good, the Bad and the Ugly,'' they were startled to learn that the subjects were all viewing the movie in basically the same way, a far more complicated notion.

headline.main: At the Movies: Brains in Sync

docs.abstract: Prof Rafael Malach of Weizmann Institute of Science, Israel, observes tendency for brains to react similarly when subjects watch same movie; research, published in journal Science, hopes to develop better understanding of multi-dimensionality of specific brain regions; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: It may seem obvious that everyone in a theater is watching the same movie.    But when neuroscientists popped test subjects into a brain scanner to see ''The Good, the Bad and the Ugly,'' they were startled to learn that the subjects were all viewing...

docs.lead_paragraph: He was a tall, gray-haired man with a pleasant face, but all you really saw was his nose. It glowed like a light bulb, red and swollen from the same disfiguring form of rosacea, called rhinophyma, that afflicted J. P. Morgan and W. C. Fields, advanced to a stage one seldom sees in public these days. Had he and I met under other circumstances, we would have discussed creams and antibiotics, referrals to dermatologists and surgeons.

headline.main: A Flyby Diagnosis On the M14

docs.abstract: Abigail Zuger Cases column discusses whether doctors should pass along information to non-patients, who show symptoms that they may be suffering from illness (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The parents of children who died unexpectedly were twice as likely to develop multiple sclerosis in the next decade as parents whose children did not die, a new Danish study reports. Researchers working on the causes of multiple sclerosis have identified a number of possible genetic and environmental factors, including stress.

headline.main: Extreme Grief Is Linked to M.S.

docs.abstract: Danish study links grief with higher incidence of multiple sclerosis; Dr Jiong Li, University of Aarhus reseacher, led study using Danish national health registry statistics and found adults who lost child younger than 18 were twice as likely to develop MS as parents whose children are still living (S)
docs.snippet: The parents of children who died unexpectedly were twice as likely to develop multiple sclerosis in the next decade as parents whose children did not die, a new Danish study reports.    Researchers working on the causes of multiple sclerosis have...

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors usually recommend a diet heavy on dairy products and light on meat and fish for people who have gout. Such diets can also help prevent the disease, researchers report in The New England Journal of Medicine. The study found that vegetable proteins like peas and beans, which gout patients are often told to avoid, actually offer some protection. Gout, an inflammation of the joints caused by a buildup of uric acid, affects as many as five million Americans, mostly men.

headline.main: Dairy Diet Found Good for Gout

docs.abstract: Dr Hyon K Choi, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, researcher, leads study on nutritional benefits of dairy products for gout patients; report, published in New England Journal of Medicine, suggests higher dairy consumption reduces risk and effects of gout; holds that higher red meat consumption appears to acerbate gout; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Doctors usually recommend a diet heavy on dairy products and light on meat and fish for people who have gout. Such diets can also help prevent the disease, researchers report in The New England Journal of Medicine.    The study found that vegetable...

docs.lead_paragraph: In recent months, three women I know said their doctors had told them they had rosacea, a facial disorder that mainly afflicts fair-skinned adults. Rosacea is commonly characterized by frequent and intense flushing or blotchy redness, the appearance of broken blood vessels on the cheeks and nose and, in some cases, acne-like pimples or pustules.

headline.main: Sometimes Rosy Cheeks Are Just Rosy Cheeks

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses rosacea, skin disorder; holds that some doctors misdiagnose rosacea when patient may simply have reddish skin or skin that flushes easily; other physicians may not recognize rosacea when present because they are unfamiliar with fairly new illness; myths about disorder discussed; symptoms of rosacea and basic treatment described; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: In recent months, three women I know said their doctors had told them they had rosacea, a facial disorder that mainly afflicts fair-skinned adults.    Rosacea is commonly characterized by frequent and intense flushing or blotchy redness, the...

docs.lead_paragraph: For almost a decade, researchers at Pfizer struggled to show that Viagra, the male impotence drug, could enhance sexual function in women. Last month, they gave up.

headline.main: In Sex, Brain Studies Show, 'la Différence' Still Holds

docs.abstract: Research findings on male and female sex drive and arousal help explain why drug companies, like Pfizer, have struggled to develop female Viagra, impotence drug; Dr Stephan Hamann, psychology professor and lead author of MRI study of men's and women's brains recently published in Nature Neuroscience, finds amygdala could be link between visual sexual stimulus and sexual pleasure; Northwestern University researcher Dr Meredith Chivers led study of visual stimulus and found that woman are visually aroused as easily as men, but do not recognize physical excitement; both studies support idea that sexual desire for women is complex physical and emotional mix and treating physical dysfunction alone will not work for most women experiencing difficulty with intimacy; photo (L)
docs.snippet: For almost a decade, researchers at Pfizer struggled to show that Viagra, the male impotence drug, could enhance sexual function in women.     Last month, they gave up.

docs.lead_paragraph: A safety program aimed at older drivers did a good job of teaching them ways to cut driving risks, but had no effect on their crash rate, a new study has found. The study's authors called the findings a dismaying parallel to the problem of educating young drivers, who, like people older than 65, have far more than their share of accidents.

headline.main: Better Drivers but Not Safer Ones

docs.abstract: Dr Cynthia Owsley and University of Alabama, Birmingham, colleagues find that senior drivers have same crash rate whether they have had intensive counseling to reduce driving risks or not; study, published in American Journal of Preventive Medicine, suggests older drivers be evaluated on regular basis (S)
docs.snippet: A safety program aimed at older drivers did a good job of teaching them ways to cut driving risks, but had no effect on their crash rate, a new study has found.     The study's authors called the findings a dismaying parallel to the problem of...

docs.lead_paragraph: There may be as many as 300,000 new cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis a year in the world, and 79 percent of them are ''superstrains,'' resistant to any three of the four first-line drugs, a World Health Organization survey has found. Patients in the former Soviet bloc countries are 10 times as likely to have drug-resistant strains as those elsewhere in the world, the survey said.

headline.main: Around the Globe, Drug-Resistant TB Is Rampant

docs.abstract: World Health Organization survey finds as many as 300,000 new cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis worldwide; former Soviet bloc countries, several provinces in China, South Africa and Ecuador have most cases, but many other nations report rise in resistant TB; possible origin of outbreak discussed; need for new tuberculosis drugs highlighted (M)
docs.snippet: There may be as many as 300,000 new cases of drug-resistant tuberculosis a year in the world, and 79 percent of them are ''superstrains,'' resistant to any three of the four first-line drugs, a World Health Organization survey has found.    Patients...

docs.lead_paragraph: Literary history is full of doctors who have taken up the writing cure. Keats was a surgeon. Rabelais was medically trained. So were Chekhov and William Carlos Williams. Dr. Jerome Groopman, a professor at the Harvard Medical School and the chief of experimental medicine at the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, is a more recent addition to the list. Seven years ago, he began publishing books and writing long articles in The New Yorker about medicine.

headline.main: At Ease With a Pen, But Also a Stethoscope

docs.abstract: Dr Jerome Groopman, Harvard Medical School professor and Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center chief of experimental medicine, discusses his new book The Anatomy of Hope; holds that hope can change brain chemistry, ease pain, improve body functions and provide peaceful death for those who cannot be cured; describes specific cases; photo (M)
